questions.question_text: When configuring monitor inputs with whitelists or blacklists, what is the supported method of filtering the lists?

discussion.content: B. Regular expression
Correction: D wildcards is incorrect as it says wildcards only so Regular Expressions is correct.

D. Wildcards:
clientName is a logical or tag name that can be assigned to a deployment client in deploymentclient.conf.
ipAddress is the IP address of the deployment client. Can use wildcards, such as 10.1.1.*
DNSname is the DNS name of the deployment client. Can use wildcards, such as *.ops.yourcompany.com
hostname is the host name of deployment client. Can use wildcards, such as *.splunk.com
instanceId is the instanceId of the client. This is a GUID string, for example: ffe9fe01-a4fb-425e-9f63-56cc274d7f8b.

Selected Answer: B
B. Regular expression
Data Admin course, page 123

Selected Answer: B
B is correct
B. Regular Expression - Page 123 - Data Admin PDF.

choices.D: None, the inputs are defined outside of Splunk.

discussion.content:

comments.content:
A : Almost all using inputs.conf, but i saw for WMI docs they are different, using wmi.conf only 

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/Data/MonitorWMIdata

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
wmi.conf: This configuration file is specifically used in Splunk to define Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) inputs. WMI is a set of specifications from Microsoft for consolidating the management of devices and applications in a network from Windows computing systems. When you want to collect data using WMI, you configure these inputs in the wmi.conf file.

questions.question_text: What configuration file are remote Windows Management Instrumentation inputs defined in?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
The answer is B since this is ingest licensing. The assumption is that there is a licensing server installed, so additional licenses will need to be installed on the licensing server and the licensing pool rearranged to distribute the licenses to the components.

Selected Answer: B
License warnings are based on the total volume of data ingested, not the data present at the time of the warning. Even if you delete data after ingestion, the volume recorded for the licensing period won't change. As qawasmih pointed out, B is the best answer.

Selected Answer: B
A & B looks correct, but prefer B

Selected Answer: B
The license manager is the central component that handles license management for your Splunk deployment

B
Need to add license on license master

choices.D: Delete the data before midnight on the license manager.
choices.B: Add a new license before midnight on the license manager.
choices.C: Delete the data before midnight on the indexer(s).
choices.A: Add a new license before midnight on the indexer(s).

questions.question_text: What action could be taken to prevent a license warning with an ingest-based license?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
the CHARSET setting in props.conf is meant to define the character encoding for specific sources of data, not for hosts.

Selected Answer: C
C. [host::server.splunk.com]
CHARSET = BIG5

Pulled from the latest GDI documentation. This is specified at the host level. A is incorrect.

Selected Answer: A
The correct example of a proper configuration for CHARSET within props.conf is specifying it at the source level, as shown in A.

questions.question_text: What is an example of a proper configuration for CHARSET within props.conf?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I agree with C as well. SEDCMS is used in the props.conf file to accomplish this.

Selected Answer: C
SEDCMS must be used with props.conf

Selected Answer: C
Answer is C, 

Splunk use SEDCMD in props.conf, 

SEDCMD-<class> = s/<regex>/<replacement>/flags

https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/latest/Data/Anonymizedata#Select_events_to_anonymize

Selected Answer: B
The transforms.conf file is used primarily for more complex data transformations, such as routing, filtering, or extracting fields. It does use REGEX directives, but these are generally applied in combination with other configurations, such as for field extractions, lookups, or routing decisions.

comments.content: Correction, I agree the Answer is C and not B. See above.
